mn55:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha in the Mango Grove of Jīvaka Komārabhacca.
mn55:2.1: Then Jīvaka went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha:
mn55:3.2: ‘They slaughter living creatures specially for the ascetic Gotama. The ascetic Gotama knowingly eats meat prepared on his behalf: this is a deed he caused.’
mn55:3.3: I trust that those who say this repeat what the Buddha has said, and do not misrepresent him with an untruth? Is their explanation in line with the teaching? Are there any legitimate grounds for rebuttal and criticism?”
mn55:4.1: “Jīvaka, those who say this do not repeat what I have said. They misrepresent me with what is false and untrue.
mn55:5.1: In three cases I say that meat may not be eaten:
mn55:5.3: These are three cases in which meat may not be eaten.
mn55:5.4: In three cases I say that meat may be eaten:
mn55:5.5: it’s not seen, heard, or suspected.
mn55:5.6: These are three cases in which meat may be eaten.
mn55:6.1: Take the case of a mendicant living supported by a town or village.
mn55:6.2: They meditate spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
mn55:6.3: A householder or their child approaches and invites them for the next day’s meal.
mn55:6.4: The mendicant accepts if they want.
mn55:6.5: When the night has passed, they robe up in the morning, take their bowl and robe, and approach that householder’s home, where they sit on the seat spread out.
mn55:6.6: That householder or their child serves them with delicious almsfood.
mn55:6.8: ‘It’s so good that this householder serves me with delicious almsfood!
mn55:6.9: I hope they serve me with such delicious almsfood in the future!’
mn55:6.11: They eat that almsfood untied, uninfatuated, unattached, seeing the drawback, and understanding the escape.
mn55:6.13: At that time is that mendicant intending to hurt themselves, hurt others, or hurt both?”
mn55:6.15: “Aren’t they eating blameless food at that time?”
mn55:7.4: Now, I’ve seen the Buddha with my own eyes,
mn55:7.5: and it is the Buddha who truly abides in love.”
mn55:7.6: “Any greed, hate, or delusion that might give rise to ill will has been given up by the Realized One, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and is unable to arise in the future.
mn55:7.7: If that’s what you were referring to, I grant it.”
mn55:7.8: “That’s exactly what I was referring to.”

mn55:11.5: and it is the Buddha who truly abides in equanimity.”

mn55:12.1: “Jīvaka, anyone who slaughters a living creature specially for the Realized One or the Realized One’s disciple brims with much wickedness for five reasons.
mn55:12.3: ‘Go, fetch that living creature,’ this is the first reason.
mn55:12.4: When that living creature experiences pain and sadness as it’s led along by a collar, this is the second reason.
mn55:12.6: ‘Go, slaughter that living creature,’ this is the third reason.
mn55:12.7: When that living creature experiences pain and sadness as it’s being slaughtered, this is the fourth reason.
mn55:12.8: When they serve the Realized One or the Realized One’s disciple with unallowable food, this is the fifth reason.
mn55:12.9: Anyone who slaughters a living creature specially for the Realized One or the Realized One’s disciple brims with much wickedness for five reasons.”
mn55:13.1: When he had spoken, Jīvaka said to the Buddha:
mn55:13.3: The mendicants indeed eat allowable food.
mn55:13.4: The mendicants indeed eat blameless food.
mn55:13.6: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
